docs.lead_paragraph: Twelve years ago I was an unwilling participant in natural childbirth. Two attempts at an epidural had failed, and finally it was too late to administer any anesthesia at all. My doctor told me that I was going to have to endure drug-free childbirth.
docs.abstract: Raleigh Mayer letter on Margaret Talbot's October 31 article disputes contention that intervention during childbirth is unnecessary

docs.lead_paragraph: I chose natural childbirth 16 months ago not because I am a fanatic or purist but because I could not in good conscience drug my baby to block my pain. While many doctors say that epidurals are safe for newborns, I feel that if, for example, drinking soda is not healthy during pregnancy, how can anesthesia be. Maureen Allen Bloomfield, N.J.
docs.abstract: Maureen Allen letter on Margaret Talbot's October 31 article believes epidurals are unsafe during childbirth

docs.lead_paragraph: If Margaret Talbot is suggesting that women who enter the hospital with a clear birth plan and seek natural childbirth are often viewed, in her words, as ''control-freak parents,'' she is right. The medical profession has always been scared of patients who are well informed and speak up for what they want. Especially women. Karen Brody Little Rock, Ark.
docs.abstract: Helen Nakdimen letter on Margaret Talbot's October 31 article on childbirth holds medical profession has always been afraid of well-informed patients, particularly women

docs.lead_paragraph: IF you worked at the Merck & Company headquarters here, during a day at the office you could leave your car for an oil change, drop off your dry cleaning and pick up laundered shirts, order a birthday cake, buy a baby gift and wrapping and have the package sent, take care of banking and ask the travel service to set up your vacation. On the way out you could rent a video and stop at the bakery, picking up dinner and a fresh baguette to take home. Those are the nice little things. The nice big things include the on-site child-care center and the health and fitness services, which include a gym and athletic fields, and free medical screenings and routine care, usually having nothing to do with the job.

headline.main: It Takes a Village To Make an Office. Ask Mother Merck.

docs.abstract: Article describes scene at Merck & Co headquarters in Whitehouse Station, NJ, which offers vast of array services, large and small, to its employees; other companies that have joined Merck, long known as generous employer, in designing corporate villages that are supportive, pleasant and inviting noted; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As one who has experienced natural childbirth three times and, thanks to midwives, never had an episiotomy, I feel grateful, proud and, I admit, morally superior. So what? Maria Schneider Brooklyn
docs.abstract: Maria Schneider letter on Margaret Talbot's October 31 article says she went through natural childbirth three times
docs.snippet: As one who has experienced natural childbirth three times and, thanks to midwives, never had an episiotomy, I feel grateful, proud and, I admit, morally superior. So what?    Maria Schneider  Brooklyn

docs.lead_paragraph: I'M not a V.J. tonight -- I'm the D.J.,'' Ananda Lewis said one recent night at Joe's Pub. Ms. Lewis, who spends her workdays introducing videos as the host of ''Hot Zone,'' a weekday MTV show, stood bopping behind the microphone in cuffed jeans, a halter top and a feathered headband. She sipped a glass of merlot, selecting an eclectic mix of CD's ranging from Alanis Morisette to Dinah Washington to Culture Club. '' 'Karma Chameleon?' '' one partygoer asked skeptically. True, it wasn't the latest hip-hop beat that many in the crowd wanted to hear, but Ms. Lewis wasn't concerned. ''I don't care if you like my taste in music or not -- it's my party tonight,'' she said, laughing.
docs.abstract: Article profiles Ananda Lewis, host of MTV television program Hot Zone and celebrity on hip-hop scene; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a world where women are constantly proving their worth -- in the office, on the playing field, at home -- unmedicated childbirth need not be singled out as ''proof'' of one's strength. Lest anyone be misled, even with today's pain blockers, childbirth is a body-racking experience, and a woman's decision to block some or most of the pain should be left unjudged. Kathryn Woodruff Washington
docs.abstract: Kathryn Woodruff letter on Margaret Talbot's October 31 article holds it should be up to woman whether to use epidural during childbirth

docs.lead_paragraph: I wholeheartedly agree with Talbot's response to natural childbirth advocates. In fact, I would go one step further and ask, What about women who cannot experience the ''empowering'' experience of childbirth? Are you going to tell me that women who adopt children are less morally or spiritually equipped to be mothers? Because that's what you are implying if you deem giving birth without drugs a singular moment. The challenge of being a mother is not enduring hardship at birth but enduring the hardship -- and joy -- that comes from being a parent. I fear that those who make such a production about the actual birth of a child are more concerned with themselves than with the child. Elizabeth Henry Jackson Heights, N.Y.
docs.abstract: Elizabeth Henry letter on Margaret Talbot's October 31 article holds women who adopt should not be considered less morally or spiritually equipped than those who experienced natural or assisted childbirth

docs.lead_paragraph: Saying that an adoption agency had deceitfully thwarted a young father's rights, a judge in Brooklyn awarded a 20-year-old man custody of his infant son on Friday, and described their two-year separation as a ''human tragedy.'' The judge, Philip C. Segal of Family Court, said in a harshly worded decision that the Catholic Home Bureau, a foster care agency, had obstructed the father's efforts to establish a relationship with his son, at one point by helping the child's mother prepare a false affidavit asserting that ''no one acting as the father'' had requested custody.

headline.main: Adoption Agency Thwarted Father's Rights, Judge Says

docs.abstract: NYC Family Court, Brooklyn, Judge Philip C Segal, saying that Catholic Home Bureau adoption agency had deceitfully thwarted young father's rights, awards man custody of his infant son (M)
